name: kazad
text: And so begins thousands of dollars worth of damage to the municipal sewage treatment system.

name: spectre
text: Yet it is damage of the sort that pays for its own repairs.

name: saint
text: but who wants to go in after all the quarters? sounds like something that would be on Dirty Jobs.

name: zaratustra
text: Magnets!

name: semiquaver
text: American coins are non-magnetic.

name: zaratustra
text: Man your money sucks.

name: semiquaver
text: Conceded.

name: tellumo
text: I will also stipulate to this. Although if you drop your American quarters through the gap between two hard-disk magnets, they'll slow waaaaay down due to the induced eddy currents and magnetic field, which is kinda cool.

name: mo_rose
text: is there any currency that will speed it up?

name: boredom_man
text: A shekel taped to a rial.

name: scorpio_nadir
text: ...this will also cause them to spin in a familiar folk-dance like the hora.

name: insomnia
text: A comment left by insomnia was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by stormypinkness, straw, ishuta, Overmedicated, Michaelangelho, sonicscream2, abe)

name: straw
text: I was thinking the exact opposite

name: dusty
text: He has to mix up the nature of his lies, if they always had the same format they would become ineffective.

name: mortshire
text: lie bot, was that lie worth a quarter?

name: straw
text: There's no true price on a well-played lie

name: greyfield
text: I'm amused by the fact that Philippe seems genuinely afraid of the quarter in Panel 3. Perhaps he's afraid of what Lie Bot is capable of?

name: history
text: Perhaps Philippe has learned the lesson that if someone gives you money they expect something in return.

name: alejandroadam
text: sometimes Liebot seems more confused than a lair. he reminds me of a meth'd out roommate.

name: tekende
text: He never seems like a lair.

name: farqussus
text: I wouldn't want to be trapped in him.

name: gunsofray
text: maybe he's hollow and evil people hide inside, which causes him to tell lies to children to distract them and cause amusement occasionally?

name: craigola
text: I worry that that's as much as Phillipe will ever do to plan for his retirement.

name: tekende
text: Philippe will never retire. He will never have anything from which to retire. He will always be five.

name: scorpio_nadir
text:
Right now it's looking alot better than most folks 401k's, which have recently flushed down the toilet.

This has been current events and crappy retirement plans with your host, Scorpio_Nadir.

name: epicurus
text: It would have taken approximately zero effort to convince me this was the gospel truth at age 5.

name: bixschmix
text: No, it would have taken exactly $.25 worth of effort. I know these things.

name: padijun
text: I'm definitely going to start telling this to other people's kids

name: lucid
text: I read that as otter people's kids without batting an eyelid at first because it made sense that Phillipe was an otter and therefore it would be fitting to do so.

name: spectre
text: Alt text: "See, all that waiting paid off. A toilet joke!"

name: dasilodavi
text: I think this is more a joke involving a toilet than an actual "toilet joke," if you catch my meaning.

name: tekende
text: Do I have to catch it? It seems pretty straightforward. "Straightforward" is one word, right? I started typing it but it looks weird to me. But it doesn't really look right any other way, either.

name: hamscout
text:
That's not all you might catch from a toilet joke...

grammar fever... catch it!

name: straw
text: I caught it once but then they had to amputate.

name: akarroa
text: That'll teach you to let your pepper touch the rim!

name: blitztrug
text:
damn man, i hate when my pepper touches the rim

also, i've only just gotten brazen enough to try bbcode

name: mattylite
text: This is the first strip where I noticed the mainline Philippe's facial expressions have to my own emotional apparatus.  I found myself normal, confused, sad that I was confused, then suddenly happy as I read it.  That otter really has a hold on me.

name: coco
text: Lie Bot puts his hands on his cold, metal stomach when he's finished telling a lie, like a fat man does when he's finished eating his sixth pork chop . . .

name: snowman
text: Lie Bot jiggling the quarter wins this strip.

name: i_love_kate
text:
Liebot states in the first strip that what he is holding is a quarter. And every person who has commented thus far has thus assumed with conviction that this is the case.

Am I the only one who sees something wrong there? You've all been so overwhelmed by the second lie that the first slipped right under your radar. And that's terrible.

name: huh
text: Yeah, but every good lie has a seed of truth in it.

name: i_love_kate
text: That strikes me as being by definition the exact opposite of a good lie.

name: huh
text: Is a good lie a lie that is believable?  If so then wouldn't a good way to make the lie believable be to give it a little bit of truth?

name: i_love_kate
text: I suppose it would rely on what your idea of a "good" lie is. Mine would be a lie that has the greatest degree of effectiveness in a truth-obscuring manner without reference to the lie's target. Thus, it would be the lie that is the farthest posible from the truth.

name: hamscout
text: LAIR!

name: wfl
text: Huh.  It looks like Lie Bot has a transparent shoulder.  You can see the line of the door bevel through it..

name: afterward
text: Certain aspects of Lie Bot are more transparent than others.
